content: In 2012 I launched a project called UpTweet.com In short, it was a system that allowed people to “upvote” each others tweets…When users upvote a sponsored tweet they get paid crypto and we take a cut. Simple right?The platform achieved some serious noteriety back then and even got an article written by my friend Vitalik Buterin: https://bitcoinmagazine.com/culture/uptweet-social-media-and-bitcoin-meet-again-1356483989The site ran for years and was able to onboard many users, but I was simply too early! Bitcoin’s price was too volatile, there was not enough people using it, and the dev tools at the time were awful.In light of recent events with Twitters new commitment to free speech and its new owner I have decided to relaunch UpTweet.com!You guys are hearing it first for 3 reasons: 1. This forum changed my life. 2. I am looking for investors who want to go on this relaunch journey with me.3. Free speech is important and I believe I have the solution to Twitters monetization problems.Key points /milestones: 1. I have all the original source code which is built in a modular, clean, MVC format. 2. Source code will need some refactoring to keep up with latest security requirements.3. Native coin for the platform will be switched from BTC to Doge for community marketing purposes.4. Once the website is active again we will activate Bitcoin and other top cryptos for sponsored advertisements.5. We will explore a compliant way to launch our own token to fuel WEB3 growth for the platform.6. Mobile apps will be released and UI “face lift” will follow.To see the site as it once was use the “Waybackmachine” or scroll through my Twitter history from 2013-2016 and you will see many campaigns that went viral. Here’s our biggest one: https://twitter.com/BrianSantoshi/status/265524962343919616Let me know what you guys think and if you want to see UpTweet come back!

comments.author: royalfestus
comments.body: My questions1. In what ways did Twitter's free speech affect an upvote project?2. In the face of spammers engaging every channel, and especially for funds, how will you handle this problem?3. It seems you haven't provided any documents to help us understand the financing and investing procedures. Could you please let us know when we can expect those documents?

comments.author: FlipPro
comments.body: Quote from: royalfestus on November 11, 2022, 09:11:17 PMMy questions1. In what ways did Twitter's free speech affect an upvote project?2. In the face of spammers engaging every channel, and especially for funds, how will you handle this problem?3. It seems you haven't provided any documents to help us understand the financing and investing procedures. Could you please let us know when we can expect those documents?1. The entire platform technology runs off Twitter. When people started getting banned/shadow banned alot of people left. Theres one legendary member in another thread I made that lost an account with 50,000 followers and no explanation. We are an upvoting platform that literally runs on twitter. There are obviously advantages and disadvantages to this play. Overall, the pros far outweigh the cons in my mind. 2. We will build out a confidence score for every user. It's very easy to pick up a bot account from a real one. If an account has a confidence score of below 70 (failing) then those users are not eligible for a payout. All payouts at the moment are manually approved. At scale our algorithm will choose who's real and who isn't. Users who feel they have accidentally been flagged can contact support for manual review once this process is live.3. I am only showing documents and going over numbers with accredited investors. If you meet that requirement feel free to message me. Otherwise, thanks for your interest!

comments.body: Quote from: TimtheYoutuber on November 14, 2022, 11:32:41 AMHow do you protect against bots upvoting? And how exactly does the monetization work for this? Bot operators will waste their valuable time trying to game the system at UpTweet.If we find accounts that are fake we ban them from the site. When a user goes to assign a payout address to their account we make them verify an email. And whenever a withdrawal request is made a captcha code is generated.All payouts are manually verified and go out weekly. UpTweet reserves the right to ban any account that may be violating our terms of services. In the future we will have an algorithm that assigns a confidence score to all accounts. With all this, along with the active war on bots currently happening on Twitter, we believe these risks will be mitigated.Quote from: examplens on November 14, 2022, 11:53:03 AMI remember this service, I know it was an interesting concept but poorly formulated. it seemed complicated to me to recognize what exactly I was doing there and the benefits of the whole thing.
